FOOTBALL SEASON LEAVES
THRILLING MEMORIES

First Performance of Season at the
Baltimore City College Hall Well
Received. "Mike" Bowers
Deserves Special Credit.

Fifteen Men Receive Their H's—Banquet and Election of 1921 Captain
on Friday—Management Now
Working on Next Year's
Schedule.

Van Orman's First Year a Big Success.
"Ed." Wood's Team Had True
Hopkins' Spirit, Four Men
Make All - Maryland
Eleven.

The Hopkins Musical Club presented its first concert of the year
last Friday night in the assembly
hall of the Baltimore City College.
The concert was a success from
start to finish. It was given primarily, for the students of City
College and Poly, but many outsiders were included in the large
and enthusiastic audience. Applause was generous, and many a
time "encores" were demanded
even after the men had left the
platform.
The first selection of the evening was a rendition of "Weinbliebtirein," an old German piece, by
the orchestra. Next was played

The Athletic Board, meeting
last Wednesday night, awarded
the "H" to members of the 1920
football team. The "H" was
given to 15 men, while two "H.
A. A.'s" were also granted.
The regulations provide that a
player must take part in 75 per
cent. of the games and must be in
each game for at least 25 per cent.
of the time to be eligible for the
letter. According to this ruling
the following men were entitled
to an "H": Capt. Ed Wood, Bill
Wood, Cashell, Benson, Jones,
Cromwell, Middleton, Knecht,
Calkins, Sandy, Morgan, Gregg,
McKay, Reed and Totterdale.

The football season just ended
was, as a whole, very gratifying to
supporters of Hopkins athletics.
The fighting spirit of the team
was evident at all times its
knowledge of the principles of the
game was very pleasing, and the
team play was never sacrificed for
the sake of individual brilliancy.
The most disappointing period of
the season, that witnessing the defeats by Virginia and Swarthmore, was quickly followed by the
fine showing against Georgetown
and three victories in a row.
Hopkins' material on two occasions in the immediate past has
been more promising than that

came and conquered 14 to 0. Several men on the Hopkins' team

It was decided to hold the banquet for the football team on December 10 at the Emerson Hotel.
At this time the captain for next
year will be elected.
The athletic authorities have
already begun the consideration of
the 1921 football schedule, but as
yet no dates have been definitely
closed. Dr. Bridgman, President
of the Varsity Club; Coach Van
Orman and Captain Wood have
held several conferences on the
subject, and are taking up the
numerous requests for contests
which continue to pour in.
A large proportion of the offers
have been from, teams in the
South, among them Virginia,
Richmond University, North Carolina, South Carolina and Washington and Lee. The State colleges are also to be considered, but

which reported to Coach Van Orman at Camp Red Cloud early in
September. But never has a better-trained, better-conditioned or
better-playing team represented
Johns Hopkins. Commencing
right from the first day at Red
Cloud, Coach Van Orman and his
old Cornell side parner, "Barney"
O'Rourke, have roughed the men
into condition. The fine playing
of "Andy" Knecht, John Markell,
"Hap" Middleton,"Jim'.' Reed and

at Red Cloud. Not least of the
good done the men at camp' was
the influence exerted over them by
Major Louis E. Lamborn, camp
director, and recently appointed
coach of the Varsity basket-ball
team.
The first game, that against Mt.
St. Mary's, resulted in an easy victory for Hopkins, which was somewhat marred by the nervousness
of the team in the first quarter.
This stage fright allowed the boys
from Emmitsburg to roll up 14

0

beat Rutgers, which had already
licked the bones of Maryland
State.
The Swarthmore game will always remain a nightmare of flying footballs and deadly sure
catches to every Hopkins man
who saw it. Nevertheless, the experience gained in the Swarthmore game proved a) very valuable
foundation for the defense against
the forward pass, which in later
games was a very encouraging feature of our team's play.
The defensive play and fighting
spirit displayed against Georg&
town, combined with "B i

recovering a fumble, filled Hopkins' cup of joy to the brim. No
one had ever dreamed that the
team could hold the Blue and Gray
to a 28 to 7 score.
The victory over Haverford,
which followed, was unusually
sweet. But the score, 17 to 10,

•THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, DECEMBER 7, 1920

2
BASKETBALL SQUAD
-ORGANIZES.
Major Lamborn, New Coach, Addresses
Candidates—Practice Starts This
Week.

There were a large number of
men out and lots of "pep" was
shown at the organization meeting of the basketball candidates.
• Manager "Jim" Reed took charge
of the meeting and introduced the,
man who will coach the team this
season, Mr. Lamborn, of Friends'
School.
Mr. Lamborn spoke of the two
things which make a winning
team: First, the spirit to win, and
second, every one doing his best.
He seemed well pleased with the
attendance and his predictions
are that Hopkins will have a most
successful season if the men go to
work with a will and sacrifice individual aspirations for team• work. Training will be strict and
during the season late hours and
tobacco are tabooed. Mr. Lamborn
will give every one a fair chance
and those showing up to the best
advantage will be given places on
the team.
Mr. Kistler, graduate manager
of athletics, spoke briefly concerning Mr. Lamborn's reputation as
a coach at Friends' School.
Preliminary practice will start
this week at Friends' School. On
account of limited facilities there
only a few men can be accommodated, but all will be given an
opportunity when practice starts
at the Fifth Regiment Armory,
where there are two large basketball floors.
The enthusiasm displayed at the
meeting by the men going out for
the team showed that they are
going into the game heart and
soul, and with the entire studentbody backing them to the limit
Major Lamborn's prediction that
Hopkins will have a most successful season cannot help but become
a reality.

Haverford and Swarthmore, both

University of Maryland is also
still problematical. Such a team
as Syracuse will not be played
during the early season, but an attempt will be made to work up
gradually to the most important
games which will be arranged for
the latter part of the schedule.
Announcement was made of the
appointment of J. B. Powell, '23,
as manager of Freshman basketball, and D. K. Vanneman,'23, as
manager of the Freshman baseball
team.

The Military Department of the
University. has put into effect an
interesting method and one that
may prove very valuable in other
University departments of keeping class work efficiency records
of every student in the unit.
The system consists of a series
of charts on which the name of
each, student is recorded and his
record portrayed graphically on
co-ordinate paper. The "Y" ordinate of the graph represents the
student's weekly mark and runs•
from 0 to 100. The "X" ordinate
represents• the date on which the
mark was given. Different subjects taught are represented by
different colored inks. By this arrangement the Professor of Military Science and Tactics can tell
at a glance at his chart on the
wall what each student is doing
and whether he has been accumulating too many absences, which
are represented by breaks in the
graph.
The new system is causing much
interest among members of the
faculty and Dr. Goodnow in particular is much interested in seeing how it will work out. Captain
MacMurray of the Military Department is the originator.of this
graphical method of *recording
student efficiency at Hopkins.
The Department of Military
Science has announced that those
students who receive an average
of 8.5 or more in their theoretical
military work for a term will not
be required to take the examination in military science at the end
of the term. This is a step forward in the question that last
year's graduating class raised
when they petitioned that those
Seniors who had attained a certain ave.rage in their studies
should not be required to take any
final examinations. It will be remembered that the petition was
not granted.

MORGANTHAU ADDRESSES
ASSEMBLY.
Former Ambassador to Turkey Gives
Interesting Talk on European Conditions Prior to War.

That German threats finally
persuaded Turkey to enter the war
as her ally, was the gist of the
address delivered at the weekly
assembly last week by the Hon.
Henry Morganthau, ambassador
to Turkey from 1913 to 1916 and
one of America's leading diplomats. There is probably no man
in the country at this time who is
better able to tell of European affairs in general and of those of
Turkey in particular prior to that
country's entrance into the war.
Being in Constantinople and in
close touch with government affairs Mr. Morgenthau was in an
ideal position for observing the
intrigue and pressure brought to
bear upon the Ottoman Government by both Germany and the
Entente.
One fact alone of particular
interest since it is not generally
TurIcey's
determined
.known
course of action—two warships
which were being built in England
for Turkey were seized by Great
Britain. The German Ambassador to Turkey took advantage of
the Turks' resentment and offered
to sell them two German warships
which were entering the port of
Constantinople. The Turks bought
the ships, but the German crews
remained, thus endangering the
Ottoman capital. Following these
conditions came the threats from
Germany that finally caused the
Turk decision.
"The preparations Turkey made
for war were nothing short of a
miracle," said the former Ambassador. "The nation was absolutely bankrupt. They formed an

CANDIDATES NEEDED FOR BLACK
AND BLUE JAY.

The initial number of the Black
and Blue Jay met with an unexpected success a large percentage
of the student-body having subscribed and numerous copies haying been sold at the Medical
School, College Courses for Teachers, Night Courses and at the
Thanksgiving game. A progressive
circulation ca.mpaign is being carried on among the alumni who
have enthusiastically given their
support.
In spite of its initial success the
earnest co-operation of the undergraduates is necessary before the
Black and _Blue Jay may hold a
permanent place in the list of
similar college publications. The
staff firmly believes that there are
.among the students literary men,
humorists, jokesters and artists
and earnestly solicits the aid of
these men in publishing the magazine..
Competition for the staff is
open and a large number of places
are available. Every one is urged
to lend a hand and make the Black
and Blue Jay a huge success. All
copy—short stories, plays, verses,
limericks, jokes and cartoons—for
the Christmas issue must be
placed in Postoffice Box 112 by
December 10.

The Military Department is engaged at present in organizing a
rifle club which will be affiliated
with the National Rifle Association of America. Membership in
the club will be open to all
students, members of the University and the faculty as well. Emphasis is laid on the fact that all
students, not merely those in the
R. 0. T. C., are eligible.
In the spring outdoor shooting
will take place at Saunders Range,
Glenburnie. An order to pay for
the materials and for the improvements Which will be made on the
range an annual charge of 50 cents
is made. By joining the club a
member is entitled to purchase
arms through the National Association at cost price.
The chief object of forming the
club at the present time is to
enable the University to be represented in the Intercollegiate Shoot
starting February 1. Under the
conditions of this competition
Hopkins would meet a different
opponent each week right here in
Baltimore.

The annual battle of wits between the Sophomore and Freshman classes will be centered this
year on the immigration problem.
The topic, "Resolved, That immigration be totally prohibited for
a period of five years," has been
chosen by a committee representing the Debating Council, Sophomore and Freshman classes. This
topic will be closely associated
with the one selected for the Varsity debate and it is most likely
immigration will engage the attention of our eloquent representatives. The Sophomores will take
the affirmative and the Freshmen
will support the negative, of the
question.
The debate will be held on Friday, January 14, at 8 P. M., in the
Civil Engineering Hall. The committee promises an enjoyable program, as the new undergraduate
orchestra has consented to furnish
the music. Heretofore at debates
and oratorical contests it had been
impossible to secure music, as the
Debating Council has always been
limited by meagre funds.
Try-outs for the representative
teams shall be held by Dr. French
on December 16 and 17 for the
Sophomore and Freshman classes,
respectively. A three-minute talk
on "The total restriction of immigration for a brief period" should
be prepared by the candidates.

BALTIMORE, MD., DEC. 7, 1920

EDITORIAL
The NEWS-LETTER regrets to announce the resignation of Mr. William Pasano, '23, from the Editorial Board.

The editor wishes to apologize
for the appearance of the NEWSLETTER last week without an editorial. The letter containing the
editorials was lost in the mail, and
the publishers sent the paper to
press without notifying him of the
loss.
THE BLACK AND BLUE JAY

A STEP IN THE RIGHT
DIRECTION
The apeparance of more postoffice boxes in the basement of
Gilman Hall is a step in the right
direction. Besides the 'need ;of
more boxes, however, boxes with
keys should be installed in place
of those already there. Combination boxes can be opened by anyone, and those from which mail
must be passed out by Mr. Myers
necessitate a great loss of time
both on his part and on the part of
the students, as well as causing
a congestion about the postoffice
window.
With a sufficient number of
boxes every student at the University should be required to take
one, just as he must pay his caution money or athletic fee. They
afford a means for the University
authorities, as well as the various
activities of reaching a student,
and every undergraduate needs
one for himself as much as for the
activities at college.

The first quarter was indecisive,

managed to work the ball into

the half ended scoreless.
With the second half the secondyear men opened up an attack
that pushed the Freshies back to
their 20-yard line, but here the
lower class braced and held for
downs. They were soon forced to
punt, however, and the Sophs came
back with forward passes from
Dodson to Rogers and Middleton,
but could not keep up their advance.
Late in the final quarter, the
Sophs succeeded in -driving their
way to the 7-yard line, from
where Rich dodged his way over
the line. Rogers kicked goal. The
game ended with the ball in midfield.
Rich proved to be the real punch
in the second-year backfield,
while Middleton and Rogers did
good work on the ends. Barton,
Harwood and Coady starred for
the Freshmen.
Between the halves of the football game the first part of the
rush was held. The Freshmen
packed together in the center of
the field, those on the outside locking arms, while the Sophs divided
into two ,bands ,and prepared -to
attack from opposite sides. Suddenly "Peanuts" Gardner was
raised above the crowd, banner in
hand, as suddenly let down again,
and the fight was on.
Aaronson, clad in what appeared to be a swimming jersey, was
hurled over the Freshmen's heads
into -the center of the throng,
while others followed with a flying leap. Soon the compact mass
had broken into a series of individual tussles, but the weenies
managed to retain the banner until
the whistle sounded.
The second engagement, which
followed the game, seemed to be
devoted largely to a methodically
conducted process of disrobement,
for the majority of the shirts on
the field soon disappeared, accompanied now and then by other and

surrounded by its quota of
opponents. Finally the whistle blew, and when Stansbury
of the Student Council reached
the center of the mob, eight Sophs
and one Freshie had their hands
on the bone of contention.
The banner was then awarded
to the Upper ellassmen, and loud
howls immediately arose from the
Freshies, who claimed that those
in at the finish arived after the
official termination of the rush.
The Student Council will probably
be called on to decide the matter
definitely.

COLOR TESTS IN PSYCHOLOGY CLASS.
Experimenting With Three Methods to
Determine Most Practical—Dr.
Dunlap in Charge.

Color vision tests have been
given to the 80 men in Psychology
I, and the same tests have been
given to a psychology class of
almost the same size at Goucher.
Three tests were given. The best
German test (Stilling's), the test
used in the air service (Jenning's) and a new test devised by
Dr. Dunlap last summer at the
research laboratory of the National Lamp Works.
The purpose of the tests is experimental, and the ultimate hope
to obtain a test which can be used
accurately and quickly on children
a13 well'as on adult-3.
It is well known that the results of the test as given in the air
service were unreliable, many
color blind men having passed the
test and received commissions.
While this failure was in part due
to incompetent administration of
the test, present results indicate
that the test is not satisfactory,
even under the best conditions.
The Stilling test is the most reliable of the tests in general use,
but presents several technical
difficulties, and is not suited for
administration to children.
At present there is no valid
basis for statements commonly
made as to the relative frequency
of color blindness and color weakness among women, as compared
with men, and it is hoped that a
test may be developed by which
statistical information on this and
other points may be obtained.
SCIENCE CLUB ANNUONCES
LECTURE.

The Undergraduate Science
Club is planning a very important
meeting for Monday, December 9.
Dr. Herman Pfund, professor of
physics, will deliver the main address, taking as his subject, "Reflectors." Though referring more
particularly to mirrors in common
use in physics and commerce he
will touch upon the properties in
general of bodies which reflect
light. A matter of such interest
as this should induce every member of the club to be present.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, DECEMBER 7, 1920
NO

PLAYLETS DURING
DECEMBER.

Plans for Second Play Night Not
Being Made. Plays for Major
Production to be Chosen
Soon.

The Dramatic Club has planned
at the beginning of the year to
have a monthly bill of playlets;
and, one night in each month, to
put on in the "Barn" a program
much like that of Tuesday, November 23, when E. M. Basford's
"Three Friends" and Joseph
Moran's "Triangle Extraordinary"
were presented. It has been
thought inadvisable, however, to
make any attempt to do this for
December and no arrangements
are being made as yet for a second
"play night."
The work of coaching the plays
has fallen chiefly on Bartus Trew,
president of the club, and he finds
that it will be impossible for him
to devote the time necessary to
put any plays on in perfected
form. Six rehearsals at least are
necessary for any play, no matter
how short, at a time when all the
cast can be present, which usually
means in the evenings.
A committee is now busy picking out a play suitable for a major
production. Just as soon as it can
be selected try-outs will be held
and work on the first act begun.
Those men who have taken parts
in the small plays will be given
preference, though they will not
be given places over any other
candidates making a better showing. It is hoped that the first act
can be finished by the Christmas
holidays and the second act begun
in January. This will prevent a
rush just before the time the play
is produced in March. Announcements for try-outs will be made
later.

Van Orman's First Year a Big Success.
"Ed." Wood's Team Had True
Hopkins' Spirit, Four Men

Eleven.

The Hopkins Musical Club presented its first concert of the year
last Friday night in the assembly
hall of the Baltimore City College.
The concert was a success from
start to finish. It was given primarily, for the students of City
College and Poly, but many outsiders were included in the large
and enthusiastic audience. Applause was generous, and many a
time "encores" were demanded
even after the men had left the
platform.
The first selection of the evening was a rendition of "Weinbliebtirein," an old German piece, by
the orchestra. Next was played

The Athletic Board, meeting
last Wednesday night, awarded
the "H" to members of the 1920
football team. The "H" was
given to 15 men, while two "H.
A. A.'s" were also granted.
The regulations provide that a
player must take part in 75 per
cent. of the games and must be in
each game for at least 25 per cent.
of the time to be eligible for the
letter. According to this ruling

BASKETBALL SQUAD
-ORGANIZES.
Major Lamborn, New Coach, Addresses
Candidates—Practice Starts This
Week.

There were a large number of
men out and lots of "pep" was
shown at the organization meeting of the basketball candidates.
• Manager "Jim" Reed took charge
of the meeting and introduced the,
man who will coach the team this
season, Mr. Lamborn, of Friends'
School.
Mr. Lamborn spoke of the two
things which make a winning
team: First, the spirit to win, and
second, every one doing his best.
He seemed well pleased with the
attendance and his predictions
are that Hopkins will have a most
successful season if the men go to
work with a will and sacrifice individual aspirations for team• work. Training will be strict and
during the season late hours and
tobacco are tabooed. Mr. Lamborn
will give every one a fair chance
and those showing up to the best
advantage will be given places on
the team.
Mr. Kistler, graduate manager
of athletics, spoke briefly concerning Mr. Lamborn's reputation as
a coach at Friends' School.
Preliminary practice will start
this week at Friends' School. On
account of limited facilities there
only a few men can be accommodated, but all will be given an
opportunity when practice starts
at the Fifth Regiment Armory,
where there are two large basketball floors.
The enthusiasm displayed at the
meeting by the men going out for
the team showed that they are
going into the game heart and
soul, and with the entire studentbody backing them to the limit
Major Lamborn's prediction that
Hopkins will have a most successful season cannot help but become
a reality.

The Military Department of the
University. has put into effect an
interesting method and one that
may prove very valuable in other
University departments of keeping class work efficiency records
of every student in the unit.
The system consists of a series
of charts on which the name of
each, student is recorded and his
record portrayed graphically on
co-ordinate paper. The "Y" ordinate of the graph represents the
student's weekly mark and runs•
from 0 to 100. The "X" ordinate
represents• the date on which the
mark was given. Different subjects taught are represented by
different colored inks. By this arrangement the Professor of Military Science and Tactics can tell
at a glance at his chart on the
wall what each student is doing
and whether he has been accumulating too many absences, which
are represented by breaks in the
graph.
The new system is causing much
interest among members of the
faculty and Dr. Goodnow in particular is much interested in seeing how it will work out. Captain
MacMurray of the Military Department is the originator.of this
graphical method of *recording
student efficiency at Hopkins.
The Department of Military
Science has announced that those
students who receive an average
of 8.5 or more in their theoretical
military work for a term will not
be required to take the examination in military science at the end
of the term. This is a step forward in the question that last
year's graduating class raised
when they petitioned that those
Seniors who had attained a certain ave.rage in their studies
should not be required to take any
final examinations. It will be remembered that the petition was
not granted.

ASSEMBLY.
Former Ambassador to Turkey Gives
Interesting Talk on European Conditions Prior to War.

That German threats finally
persuaded Turkey to enter the war
as her ally, was the gist of the
address delivered at the weekly
assembly last week by the Hon.
Henry Morganthau, ambassador
to Turkey from 1913 to 1916 and
one of America's leading diplomats. There is probably no man
in the country at this time who is
better able to tell of European affairs in general and of those of
Turkey in particular prior to that
country's entrance into the war.
Being in Constantinople and in
close touch with government affairs Mr. Morgenthau was in an
ideal position for observing the
intrigue and pressure brought to
bear upon the Ottoman Government by both Germany and the
Entente.
One fact alone of particular
interest since it is not generally
TurIcey's
determined
.known
course of action—two warships
which were being built in England
for Turkey were seized by Great
Britain. The German Ambassador to Turkey took advantage of
the Turks' resentment and offered
to sell them two German warships
which were entering the port of
Constantinople. The Turks bought
the ships, but the German crews
remained, thus endangering the
Ottoman capital. Following these
conditions came the threats from
Germany that finally caused the
Turk decision.
"The preparations Turkey made
for war were nothing short of a
miracle," said the former Ambassador. "The nation was absolutely bankrupt. They formed an

R. 0. T. C., are eligible.

conditions of this competition
Hopkins would meet a different
opponent each week right here in

The annual battle of wits between the Sophomore and Freshman classes will be centered this
year on the immigration problem.
The topic, "Resolved, That immigration be totally prohibited for
a period of five years," has been
chosen by a committee representing the Debating Council, Sophomore and Freshman classes. This
topic will be closely associated
with the one selected for the Varsity debate and it is most likely
immigration will engage the attention of our eloquent representatives. The Sophomores will take
the affirmative and the Freshmen
will support the negative, of the
question.
The debate will be held on Friday, January 14, at 8 P. M., in the
Civil Engineering Hall. The committee promises an enjoyable program, as the new undergraduate
orchestra has consented to furnish
the music. Heretofore at debates
and oratorical contests it had been
impossible to secure music, as the
Debating Council has always been
limited by meagre funds.
Try-outs for the representative
teams shall be held by Dr. French
on December 16 and 17 for the
Sophomore and Freshman classes,
respectively. A three-minute talk
on "The total restriction of immigration for a brief period" should
be prepared by the candidates.

EDITORIAL
The NEWS-LETTER regrets to announce the resignation of Mr. William Pasano, '23, from the Editorial Board.

The editor wishes to apologize
for the appearance of the NEWSLETTER last week without an editorial. The letter containing the
editorials was lost in the mail, and

THE BLACK AND BLUE JAY

A STEP IN THE RIGHT
DIRECTION
The apeparance of more postoffice boxes in the basement of
Gilman Hall is a step in the right
direction. Besides the 'need ;of
more boxes, however, boxes with
keys should be installed in place
of those already there. Combination boxes can be opened by anyone, and those from which mail
must be passed out by Mr. Myers
necessitate a great loss of time
both on his part and on the part of
the students, as well as causing
a congestion about the postoffice
window.
With a sufficient number of
boxes every student at the University should be required to take
one, just as he must pay his caution money or athletic fee. They
afford a means for the University
authorities, as well as the various
activities of reaching a student,
and every undergraduate needs
one for himself as much as for the
activities at college.

the Freshmen.
Between the halves of the football game the first part of the
rush was held. The Freshmen
packed together in the center of
the field, those on the outside locking arms, while the Sophs divided
into two ,bands ,and prepared -to
attack from opposite sides. Suddenly "Peanuts" Gardner was
raised above the crowd, banner in
hand, as suddenly let down again,
and the fight was on.
Aaronson, clad in what appeared to be a swimming jersey, was
hurled over the Freshmen's heads
into -the center of the throng,
while others followed with a flying leap. Soon the compact mass
had broken into a series of individual tussles, but the weenies
managed to retain the banner until
the whistle sounded.
The second engagement, which
followed the game, seemed to be
devoted largely to a methodically
conducted process of disrobement,
for the majority of the shirts on
the field soon disappeared, accompanied now and then by other and
The
more necessary articles.
Freshmen were gradually separated into two bodies, each
surrounded by its quota of
opponents. Finally the whistle blew, and when Stansbury
of the Student Council reached
the center of the mob, eight Sophs
and one Freshie had their hands
on the bone of contention.
The banner was then awarded
to the Upper ellassmen, and loud
howls immediately arose from the
Freshies, who claimed that those
in at the finish arived after the
official termination of the rush.
The Student Council will probably
be called on to decide the matter
definitely.

COLOR TESTS IN PSYCHOLOGY CLASS.
Experimenting With Three Methods to
Determine Most Practical—Dr.
Dunlap in Charge.

Color vision tests have been
given to the 80 men in Psychology
I, and the same tests have been
given to a psychology class of
almost the same size at Goucher.
Three tests were given. The best
German test (Stilling's), the test
used in the air service (Jenning's) and a new test devised by
Dr. Dunlap last summer at the
research laboratory of the National Lamp Works.
The purpose of the tests is experimental, and the ultimate hope
to obtain a test which can be used
accurately and quickly on children
a13 well'as on adult-3.
It is well known that the results of the test as given in the air
service were unreliable, many
color blind men having passed the
test and received commissions.
While this failure was in part due
to incompetent administration of
the test, present results indicate
that the test is not satisfactory,
even under the best conditions.
The Stilling test is the most reliable of the tests in general use,
but presents several technical
difficulties, and is not suited for
administration to children.
At present there is no valid
basis for statements commonly
made as to the relative frequency
of color blindness and color weakness among women, as compared
with men, and it is hoped that a
test may be developed by which
statistical information on this and
other points may be obtained.
SCIENCE CLUB ANNUONCES
LECTURE.

The Undergraduate Science
Club is planning a very important
meeting for Monday, December 9.
Dr. Herman Pfund, professor of
physics, will deliver the main address, taking as his subject, "Reflectors." Though referring more
particularly to mirrors in common
use in physics and commerce he
will touch upon the properties in
general of bodies which reflect
light. A matter of such interest
as this should induce every member of the club to be present.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, DECEMBER 7, 1920
NO

PLAYLETS DURING
DECEMBER.

Plans for Second Play Night Not
Being Made. Plays for Major
Production to be Chosen
Soon.

The Dramatic Club has planned
at the beginning of the year to
have a monthly bill of playlets;
and, one night in each month, to
put on in the "Barn" a program
much like that of Tuesday, November 23, when E. M. Basford's
"Three Friends" and Joseph
Moran's "Triangle Extraordinary"
were presented. It has been
thought inadvisable, however, to
make any attempt to do this for
December and no arrangements
are being made as yet for a second
"play night."
The work of coaching the plays
has fallen chiefly on Bartus Trew,
president of the club, and he finds
that it will be impossible for him
to devote the time necessary to
put any plays on in perfected
form. Six rehearsals at least are
necessary for any play, no matter
how short, at a time when all the
cast can be present, which usually
means in the evenings.
A committee is now busy picking out a play suitable for a major
production. Just as soon as it can
be selected try-outs will be held
and work on the first act begun.
Those men who have taken parts
in the small plays will be given
preference, though they will not
be given places over any other
candidates making a better showing. It is hoped that the first act
can be finished by the Christmas
holidays and the second act begun
in January. This will prevent a
rush just before the time the play
is produced in March. Announcements for try-outs will be made
later.
